clinical_study.brief_title: Home-Based Symptom Monitoring: Its Impact on Cancer Care Team Behaviors and Patient Outcomes
clinical_study.official_title: Home-Based Symptom Monitoring: Its Impact on Cancer Care Team Behaviors and Patient Outcomes

brief_summary.textblock: The primary research objective of this protocol is to evaluate the impact of integrating a home-based symptom monitoring system in the day-to-day care of cancer patients in community settings on the frequency of supportive symptom interventions, symptom severity, and quality of life.

detailed_description.textblock: Patients will be randomly assigned to one of two groups. One group will be offered an Internet assisted home-based symptom reporting system Cancer Symptom Monitor (CSM) for a twelve-month study period. Patient and care team evaluations will be measured using quantitative and qualitative methods (via focus groups). The second group will receive "standard care" without home-based symptom monitoring. Both groups will be evaluated at baseline, 1, 2, 3, 6, 9, & 12 months, for symptom levels and overall quality of life during the twelve-month study period.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
18 years old or older Diagnosis of solid tumor or hematologic malignancy Starting active treatment (chemotherapy or hormonal therapy) Must be able to give informed consent & consent to use the Cancer Symptom Monitor -
Exclusion Criteria:
Inability to give informed consent Life expectancy of less than 3 months Subject has any kind of disorder that compromises the ability of the subject to give written informed consent and/or to comply with study procedures.
